JNL01$1001—11-10-01 10:09:29      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 2001                        1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo-
ber 2000 Term of the Supreme Court is now closed and the October
Term 2001 is now convened.
   “Before we hear the first argument, let us take a moment to recog-
nize the terrible loss caused by the terrorist attacks on America that
occurred on September 11th. I know our hearts go out to the families
of those killed and injured. We extend our condolences to the Solicitor
General of the United States for the loss of his wife Barbara.
   “In the aftermath of the attacks, we have witnessed extraordinary
bravery and compassion from Americans from all walks of life. Let us
take a moment to grieve with those who mourn, and honor those who
have historically performed their duty.’
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 00–1649. County of Humboldt, et al., Petitioners v. Headwaters
Forest Defense, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration
in light of Saucier v. Katz, 533 U. S. 194 (2001).
   No. 00–1875. Time Warner Entertainment Company, et al., Petition-
ers v. Six Flags Over Georgia, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the Court of Appeals of Georgia. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Geor-
gia for further consideration in light of Cooper Industries, Inc. v.
Leatherman Tool Group, 532 U. S. 424 (2001).
   No. 00–9044. Rogers Lee Jackson, Petitioner v. Larry Massanari,
Acting Commissioner of Social Security. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
JNL01$1001—11-10-01 10:09:29      JOURNAPGT           MILES




2                         MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 2001

the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further
consideration in light of the position presently asserted by the Solicitor
General in his brief for the Acting Commissioner of Social Security
filed June 20, 2001.

162                      MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 2001

petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance
with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals,
506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4,
and cases cited therein.

in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit dismissed. See
Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process,
the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal
matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin
v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per cu-
riam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

166                     MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 2001

writ of mandamus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeat-
edly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

  No. D–2238. In the Matter of Disbarment of Dushko S. Zdravkovich.

requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.

                            Oral Arguments
  No. 00–860. Correctional Services Corporation, Petitioner v. John E.
Malesko. Argued by Mr. Carter G. Phillips for the petitioner, by
Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken for the United States as amicus curiae, by
special leave of the Court, supporting the petitioner, and by Mr. Steven
Pasternak for the respondent.
  No. 99–1786. Great-West Life & Annuity Insurance Company, et al.,
Petitioners v. Janette Knudson, et vir. Argued by Mr. James F. Jorden
for the petitioners, by Mr. Paul R. Q. Wolfson for the United States as
amicus curiae, by special leave of the Court, supporting the petition-
ers, and by Mr. Richard G. Taranto invited by this Court to brief and
argue as amicus curiae in support of the judgment below.


  Adjourned until Tuesday, October 2, 2001, at 10 o’clock.


                           Certiorari Granted
  No. 00–1781. Oakland Housing Authority, et al., Petitioners v.
Pearlie Rucker, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. The case is
consolidated with No. 00–1770, Department of Housing and Urban De-
velopment v. Rucker, and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argu-
ment. Justice Breyer took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition and order.

(JOURNAL)                 TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9, 2001                      201
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                    Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 01–75. Patricia E. Gentala, et vir, Petitioners v. City of Tucson.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Good News Club
v. Milford Central School, 533 U. S. 98 (2001).
   No. 01–176. National Union Fire Insurance Company of Pittsburgh,
Pennsylvania, Petitioner v. Textron Financial Corporation. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Ap-
pellate District. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth
Appellate District, for further consideration in light of Cooper Indus-
tries, Inc. v. Leatherman Tool Group, 532 U. S. 424 (2001).

                       Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 01M16. Margie Maness, Petitioner v. George Fuller, et al. Motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time
denied.
  No. 00–1514. Lance Raygor and James Goodchild, Petitioners v. Re-
gents of the University of Minnesota, et al. Motion of the United States
to intervene granted.
  No. 01–188. Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of
America, Petitioner v. Kevin Concannon, Commissioner, Maine Depart-
ment of Human Services, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file
a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
  No. 01–270. Yellow Freight System, Inc., Petitioner v. Michigan,
et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case express-
ing the views of the United States.

Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local No. 48, et al. Motion to direct
the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
  No. 01M18. Beverly Butler, Petitioner v. West Virginia, et al. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indi-
gency executed by petitioner is denied.
  No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
Motion of the River Master for fees and reimbursement of expenses
granted, and the River Master is awarded a total of $2,970.18 for the
period April 1, 2001–June 30, 2001, to be paid equally by the parties.
  No. 01–6209. Thomas L. Groeber, Petitioner v. United States Postal
Service. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
denied. Petitioner allowed until November 5, 2001, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.

                         MONDAY, OCTOBER 15, 2001                   253
nied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner
has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not
to accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste-
vens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 00–1214. Alabama, Petitioner v. LeReed Shelton. This case is
removed from the November 2001 Argument Calendar. Charles Fried,
Esquire, of Cambridge, Massachusetts, is invited to file a brief, and to
argue, as amicus curiae, in opposition to the judgment below and in
support of the following position: where counsel is not afforded to an
indigent defendant, the Constitution of the United States does not bar
the imposition of a suspended or probationary sentence upon conviction
of a misdemeanor, even though the defendant might be incarcerated in
the event probation is revoked. The brief as amicus curiae is to be
filed with the Clerk and served upon the parties on or before 3 p.m.,
Monday, December 10, 2001. Any response by the parties may be filed
with the Clerk and served upon opposing parties and amicus curiae
on or before 3 p.m., Friday, January 11, 2002. Rule 29.2 is suspended in
this case. Ten minutes of petitioner’s time are allotted to Mr. Fried for
oral argument.
JNL01$1022—11-08-01 18:56:04    JOURNAPGT          MILES

JNL01$1029—10-19-02 18:48:50     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 2001                   273
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present in the E. Barrett Prettyman United States Courthouse:
Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor, Justice
Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Gins-
burg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Before we hear the first argument, I would like to make a brief
statement. This is the first time our Court has met outside our building
since the building opened in 1935.
   “My colleagues and I want to thank the staff of the Supreme Court
and the judges and staff of the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit, and the United States District Court for
District of Columbia, whose hard work made it possible for us to hear
oral arguments this morning.
   “We will also hear arguments in this building tomorrow.
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

   No. 01–6063. In Re Robert Roy Butcher, Petitioner. Petition for
writ of mandamus denied.
   No. 01–5362. In Re Alaba O. Awofolu, Petitioner. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for
writ of mandamus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeat-
edly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 01–5964. In Re Joseph Johnson, Jr., Petitioner. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for
writ of mandamus and/or prohibition dismissed. See Rule 39.8.

from the practice of law in this Court.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present in the E. Barrett Prettyman United States Courthouse:
Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor, Justice
Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Gins-
burg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “We will also hear arguments in this building tomorrow.”

the respondent.

a brief as amici curiae granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the

344                    TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 2001

                        Attorney Discipline
   No. D–2270. In the Matter of Bill Clinton. Bill Clinton, of New York,
New York, having requested to resign as a member of the Bar of this
Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys
admitted to the practice of law before this Court. The Rule to Show
Cause, issued on October 1, 2001, is discharged.
   No. D–2282. In the Matter of Discipline of Geoffrey Paul Kelly. Geof-
frey Paul Kelly, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2283. In the Matter of Discipline of Levi England. Levi Eng-
land, of Hollywood, Florida, is suspended from the practice of law in
this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.
   No. D–2284. In the Matter of Discipline of Steven Stanford Griswold.
Steven Stanford Griswold, of Prairie Village, Kansas, is suspended
from the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2285. In the Matter of Discipline of Charles Dawson Mat-
thews. Charles Dawson Matthews, of Bella Vista, Arkansas, is sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue,
returnable within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

                            Recess Order
 The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, November 13, 2001, until
Monday, November 26, 2001.

   No. D–2266. In the Matter of Maria Cristina Gutierrez. Maria Cris-
tina Gutierrez, of Towson, Maryland, having requested to resign as a
JNL01$1126—10-19-02 18:54:25     JOURNAPGT         MILES




                       MONDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 2001                  371
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that her name be

fore this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, issued on October 1, 2001,
is discharged.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice

                               Opinions
   No. 00–507. Chickasaw Nation, Petitioner v. United States; and
Chocktaw Nation of Oklahoma, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.
Judgments affirmed. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Justice Scalia and Jus-
tice Thomas join all but Part II-B of this opinion. Dissenting opinion
by Justice O’Connor with whom Justice Souter joins.
   No. 00–860. Correctional Services Corporation, Petitioner v. John E.
Malesko. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The
Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Justice
Thomas joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join.
   No. 00–730. Adarand Constructors, Inc., Petitioner v. Norman Y. Mi-
neta, Secretary of Transportation, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Writ of certiorari
dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by
The Chief Justice.

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 00–1115. United States, Petitioner v. Little Six, Inc., and Shako-
pee Mdewakanton Sioux (Dakota) Community. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Cir-
cuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Cir-
cuit for further consideration in light of Chickasaw Nation v. United
States, 534 U. S. ––– (2001).

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 01–285. Maryellen Thoms, Warden, Petitioner v. Mario Rosales-
Garcia. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Zadvydas v. Davis, 533 U. S. 678 (2001).

Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit granted limited to the following question: Given
that a finding of “brandishing", as used in 18 U. S. C. Sec. 924(c)(1)(A),
results in an increased mandatory minimum sentence, must the fact
of “brandishing” be alleged in the indictment and proved beyond a
reasonable doubt?

petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

(JOURNAL)             WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 2001                  413
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Souter, Justice Kennedy, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                        Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 01–339. Terry L. Stewart, Director, Arizona Department of Cor-
rections, Petitioner v. Robert Douglas Smith. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Motion of the Criminal Justice Legal Foundation for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Question certified to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Judgment and
further proceedings in this case reserved pending receipt of a response
from the Supreme Court of Arizona. Opinion per curiam.


                     Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 00–1531. Verizon Maryland Inc., Petitioner v. Public Service
Commission of Maryland, et al.; and
  No. 00–1711. United States, Petitioner v. Public Service Commission
of Maryland, et al. Petitions for certiorari in these cases presented
the same questions at issue in Mathias v. WorldCom Technologies,
No. 00–878, plus the additional question of subject matter jurisdiction
under 28 U. S. C. § 1331. We granted certiorari only on the additional
question, and held the other questions pending their resolution in Ma-
thias, supra. Oral argument has revealed, however, that we may be
unable to reach the merits of the questions presented in Mathias.
Therefore, to ensure that we have jurisdiction over all of the questions
at issue in these cases, petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted on the remain-
ing questions presented by the petitions, and request that the parties
brief those questions. Briefs of petitioners to be filed with the Clerk
and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, January
11, 2002. Respondents’ briefs to be filed with the Clerk and served
upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, February 1, 2002.
Reply briefs, if any, to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing
counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, February 15, 2002. Petitioners’
JNL01$1212—01-04-02 21:03:36    JOURNAPGT            MILES




414                   WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 2001

opening briefs and respondents’ briefs shall not exceed 25 pages. Peti-
tioners’ reply briefs, if any, shall not exceed 15 pages. Rule 29.2 sus-
pended in these cases. Justice O’Connor took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this order.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

                       Order in Pending Case

  No. 00–1853. Akos Swierkiewicz, Petitioner v. Sorema N.A. Motion
of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as
amicus curiae and for divided argument granted.

                         Certiorari Granted

   No. 01–309. Larry Hope, Petitioner v. Mark Pelzer, et al. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit granted.
   No. 01–419. City of Columbus, et al., Petitioners v. Ours Garage and
Wrecker Service, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted.
   No. 01–455. Franconia Associates, et al., Petitioners v. United
States; and Grass Valley Terrace, et al., Petitioners v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit granted limited to the following questions: 1.
Whether a breach of contract claim accrues for purposes of 28 U.S.C.
§ 2501 when Congress enacts a statute alleged to abridge a contractual
right to freedom from regulatory covenants upon prepayment of gov-
ernment mortgage loans. 2. Whether a Fifth Amendment takings claim
accrues for purposes of 28 U. S. C. § 2501 when Congress enacts a stat-
ute alleged to abridge a contractual right to freedom from regulatory
covenants upon prepayment of government mortgage loans.
   No. 01–518. BE&K Construction Company, Petitioner v. National
Labor Relations Board, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted limited
to the following question: Did the Court of Appeals err in holding that
under Bill Johnson’s Restaurants, Inc. v. NLRB, 461 U.S. 731 (1983),
the NLRB may impose liability on an employer for filing a losing retal-
iatory lawsuit, even if the employer could show the suit was not objec-
tively baseless under Professional Real Estate Investors, Inc. v. Co-
lumbia Pictures Industries, Inc., 508 U. S. 49 (1993)?
JNL01$0104—10-19-02 19:01:15    JOURNAPGT          MILES

(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, JANUARY 7, 2002                     419
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  Justice Stevens said:
  “Mr. Chief Justice, if you do not object, I shall open the proceedings
this morning by taking note of the fact that this is the 30th Anniversary
of your swearing-in as a Member of this Court. With one exception,
you are the only Chief Justice who has been active for 30 years—that
exception was John Marshall with whom, I am sure, you will happily
share the honor.
  “On behalf of all of your colleagues, I want to express our sincere
appreciation for the exemplary way in which you have performed the
special responsibilities of your high office, with particular emphasis
on the efficiency, good humor, and absolute impartiality that you have
consistently displayed when presiding at our Conferences.
  “In a different setting, I would propose a toast to you, but, here I
shall merely express our thanks for your 30 years of dedicated service
to our Country.”
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Thank you, Justice Stevens. Today’s orders of the Court have been
certified by The Chief Justice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not
be otherwise announced.”

                      Orders in Pending Cases

   No. 01M31. Corey Weidner, Petitioner v. Oregon State Correctional
Institution, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ
of certiorari out-of-time denied.
  No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. Final motion of the Special Master for compensation and
reimbursement of expenses granted, and the Special Master is awarded
a total of $297,888.18 to be paid as follows: 42% each by Nebraska
and Wyoming, 10% by the United States, and 6% by Basin Electric
Power Cooperative.
  No. 00–878. Richard L. Mathias, et al., Petitioners v. WorldCom
Technologies, Inc., et al. Motion of respondent Illinois Bell Telephone
Company for leave to file a supplemental brief after argument denied.

ment denied without prejudice to filing a brief addressing only the

   No. 00–1531. Verizon Maryland Inc., Petitioner v. Public Service

   No. 00–1711. United States, Petitioner v. Public Service Commission

   No. 00–1751. Susan Tave Zelman, Superintendent of Public Instruc-

   No. 01–6875. Isaac Ford, Petitioner v. California. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appel-
late District, dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 01–7029. Albert Thomas, Petitioner v. Alan Carter, et al. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 01–7081. Hector Camarena, Petitioner v. Department of the

of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner
has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   No. 99–1786. Great-West Life & Annuity Insurance Company, et al.,
Petitioners v. Janette Knudson and Eric Knudson. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Ste-
vens, Justice Souter, and Justice Breyer join.

tioner v. Ella Williams. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice O’Connor.
  No. 00–6567. Larry Dean Dusenbery, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Stevens, Justice Sou-
ter, and Justice Breyer join.

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of of South Carolina. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court of South Carolina
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.

Thomas with whom Justice Scalia joins.

manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Stevens. Justice Scalia took no part in the decision of
this case.

for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the

25, 2002. Respondent’s brief is to be filed with the Clerk and served
upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Wednesday, March 27, 2002.
Reply brief, if any, to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing
counsel on or before 3 p.m., Monday, April 15, 2002. Rule 29.2 is sus-
pended in this case.

day, April 15, 2002. Rule 29.2 is suspended in this case.

  No. 00–1249. Caren Cronk Thomas and Windy City Hemp Develop-

ment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia.
   No. 99–1823. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Peti-
tioner v. Waffle House, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas,
with whom The Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join.

certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice Scalia.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia,
Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Appeal—Summary Disposition

  No. 01–721. Norman M. Robertson, et al., Appellants v. Larry Bar-
tels, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of New Jersey. Judgment affirmed.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

  No. 00–1503. City of Gainesville, Petitioner v. Cannabis Action Net-
work, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certio-
rari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consider-
ation in light of Thomas v. Chicago Park District, 534 U. S. ––– (2002).

Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indi-

tional Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers for leave to participate
in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument granted
to be divided as follows: 20 minutes for respondent and 10 minutes for
amicus curiae. Motion of petitioner for additional time for oral argu-
ment denied. Order of October 1, 2001, granting the motion of Texas,
et al., for leave to participate in oral argument as amici curiae and for
divided argument rescinded.

Commission of Maryland, et al.; and

                        Order in Pending Case
   No. 01–309. Larry Hope, Petitioner v. Mark Pelzer, et al. Order
granting petition for writ of certiorari amended as follows: “Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted limited to the follow questions:
1. Whether state officials sued in their individual capacities under
42 U. S. C. § 1983 are entitled to qualified immunity unless they have
violated statutory or constitutional rights ‘clearly established’ by a
case presenting facts ‘materially similar’ to those in the plaintiff ’s case.
2. Whether under the circumstances that must be taken as true at the
summary judgment stage of this case, tying a prisoner to a ‘hitching
post’ violates ‘clearly established’ constitutional rights for purposes of
qualified immunity under 42 U. S. C. § 1983.”

ted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia

                       Attorney Discipline

   No. D–2254. In the Matter of Chuck R. Stidham. Chuck R. Stidham,
of Cincinnati, Ohio, having requested to resign as a member of the Bar
of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of
attorneys admitted to the practice of law before this Court. The Rule
to Show Cause, issued on September 7, 2001, is discharged.

568                       TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 2002

                                 Opinions

   No. 00–1307. Jo Anne B. Barnhart, Commissioner of Social Security,
Petitioner v. Sigmon Coal Company, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens with whom Justice O’Connor and Justice Breyer join.
   No. 00–1073. Owasso Independent School District No. I–011, aka
Owasso Public Schools, et al., Petitioners v. Kristja J. Falvo, Parent
and Next Friend of Her Minor Children, Elizabeth Pletan, Philip
Pletan, and Erica Pletan. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in
the judgment.

                            Oral Arguments

  No. 00–1214. Alabama, Petitioner v. LeReed Shelton. Argued by
Mr. William H. Pryor, Jr., for the petitioner, by Mr. Charles Fried by
invitation of the Court as amicus curiae, in opposition to the judgment
below, by Mr. William H. Mills for the respondent, and by Mr. Steven
B. Duke for the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers as
amicus curiae, by special leave of the Court, in support of respondent.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice

  No. 00–952. Wisconsin Department of Health and Family Services,
Petitioner v. Irene Blumer. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Ap-
peals of Wisconsin, District IV. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin, Division IV, for further proceed-
ing not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Ginsburg. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
O’Connor and Justice Scalia join.

(JOURNAL)               MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 2002                   573
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 00–725. Aloe Energy Corporation, Petitioner v. Jo Anne B. Barn-
hart, Commissioner of Social Security. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further
consideration in light of Barnhart v. Sigmon Coal Company, 534 U. S.
––– (2002).
   No. 00–9046. Alexander Martinelli, Petitioner v. Minnesota. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Minnesota. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals of Minnesota for further consideration in light of
Kansas v. Crane, 534 U. S. ––– (2002).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 00–10666. William Joseph Harris, Petitioner v. United States.

liam C. Ingram, Esquire, of Greensboro, North Carolina, is appointed
to serve as counsel for petitioner in this case.
   No. 00–10747. William Lebron Andrew Church, Petitioner v. Vir-
ginia. Motion of petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave
to proceed in forma pauperis denied.
   No. 00–10748. In Re William L. Church, Petitioner. Motion of peti-

pauperis denied.
   No. 00–10761. In Re William L. Church, Petitioner. Motion of peti-
tioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed in forma
pauperis denied.

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 00–1619. Glenn S. Goord, Commissioner, New York Department
of Correctional Services, et al., Petitioners v. Robert Lawrence. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of Porter
v. Nussle, 534 U. S. ––– (2002).
   No. 01–100. William Sterner, et al., Petitioners v. John P. Roys-
ter, Sr. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of
Porter v. Nussle, 534 U. S. ––– (2002).

process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in

33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1
(1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases
cited therein.

40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred

not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–2288. In the Matter of Discipline of Michael J. Friesen. Mi-
chael J. Friesen, of Garden City, Kansas, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–2289. In the Matter of Discipline of James Guy Tucker, Jr.
James Guy Tucker, Jr., of Little Rock, Arkansas, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–2290. In the Matter of Discipline of Murrey L. Grider. Murrey
L. Grider, of Pocahontas, Arkansas, is suspended from the practice of
law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 01A557. Washington Department of Social and Health Services,
et al., Applicants v. Guardianship Estate of Danny Keffeler, et al. Ap-
plication for stay presented to Justice O’Connor and by her referred to
the Court granted, and it is ordered that the stay granted by Justice
O’Connor on January 29, 2002, shall continue and the mandate of the
Supreme Court of Washington, case No. 67680-1, issued on December
14, 2001, is stayed pending the timely filing and disposition of the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ of certiorari be
denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In the event the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall terminate upon
issuance of the mandate of this Court.

tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                    Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 00–1643. United States, Petitioner v. Henry Alexander Jones.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of United States v.
Vonn, 535 U. S. ––– (2002).

mission, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As
petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is di-
rected not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from
petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and
petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District
of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice
Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

(JOURNAL)                TUESDAY, MARCH 19, 2002                   671
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
                               Opinions
   No. 00–1072. Leonard Edelman, Petitioner v. Lynchburg College. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.
Concurring opinion by Justice Thomas. Opinion by Justice O’Connor,
with whom Justice Scalia joins, concurring in the judgment.
   No. 00–6029. Tracy Ragsdale, et al., Petitioners v. Wolverine World
Wide, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy.
Dissenting opinion by Justice O’Connor with whom Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join.

  No. 01–1103. James D. Boswell, Petitioner v. Board of Trustees of
Texas Christian University, et al.; and James D. Boswell, Petitioner v.
Texas Christian University, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed as a veteran granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
  No. 01–1246. Ted Stevenson Angwin, Petitioner v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit denied. Justice Breyer took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this petition.
  No. 01–7785. James Bernard Lawson, Petitioner v. Mississippi, et al.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied,
and petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Mississippi
dismissed. See Rule 39.8.
  No. 01–7889. Aziz Safouane, et ux., Petitioners v. Washington De-
partment of Social and Health Services. Motion of petitioners for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari
to the Court of Appeals of Washington, Division One, dismissed. See
Rule 39.8.
  No. 01–7924. Frizelle Aguilar, aka Frizelle L. Aguilar Riley Ozman,
Petitioner v. New Mexico. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the
District Court of New Mexico, Bernalillo County, dismissed. See Rule
39.8.
  No. 01–7929. Ben F. Gyadu, Petitioner v. D’Addario Industries, Inc.,
et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis de-
nied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Con-
necticut dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused
this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further
petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance
with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals,
506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4,
and cases cited therein.
  No. 01–8031. Darrell S. Cottrell, Petitioner v. Director, Office of
Workers’ Compensation Programs, United States Department of
Labor. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Justice Scalia took no part in
the consideration or decision of this petition.

   No. 00–1937. Jo Anne B. Barnhart, Commissioner of Social Security,
Petitioner v. Cleveland B. Walton. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Opinion by Justice Scalia
concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.
   No. 00–9285. Walter Mickens, Jr., Petitioner v. John Taylor, Warden.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom Justice O’Connor joins.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Souter. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer with whom Justice Gins-
burg joins.
   No. 00–1595. Hoffman Plastic Compounds, Inc., Petitioner v. Na-
tional Labor Relations Board. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the District of Columbia Circuit for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice Stevens, Justice
Souter, and Justice Ginsburg join.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, APRIL 1, 2002                     701
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice O’Connor, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                        Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 01–835. Sao Paulo State of the Federative Republic of Brazil,
Petitioner v. American Tobacco Co., Inc., et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Fifth Circuit granted. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.

                   Appeal—Summary Disposition
  No. 01–1114. David Winters, et al., Appellants v. Illinois State Board
of Elections, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Illinois. Judgment affirmed.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 01–948. Dave Dormire, Superintendent, Jefferson City Correc-
tional Center, Petitioner v. James Koste. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Mickens v. Taylor, 535 U. S. –––
(2002).

  No. 01M43. Lionel Bernard Dennis, Petitioner v. Tydus Meadows,

out-of-time denied.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 01–9454. Gary Leon Brown, Petitioner v. Alabama. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy
and by him referred to the Court granted pending the disposition of
the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ of certio-
rari be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In the event the
petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall terminate upon
issuance of the mandate of this Court.

   No. 01–8161. Roberto Baez, Petitioner v. Nike Incorporated, et al.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied,
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has re-
peatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 01–8519. Andrew J. Johnson, Petitioner v. David L. Serelson,

                                 Order
  It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the Term upon conclusion of the cases listed
for hearing on Wednesday, April 24, 2002.

JNL01$0416—04-22-02 18:52:13      JOURNAPGT         MILES




(JOURNAL)                 TUESDAY, APRIL 16, 2002                    777
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “As we open this morning, I want to pay tribute to our friend and
colleague Byron R. White, a retired Justice of this Court, who died
yesterday morning in Colorado.
   “Byron White was nominated to the Court by President Kennedy on
April 3, 1962, and was confirmed by the Senate eight days later. He
took the oath of office forty years ago today, on April 16, 1962. He was
the 93rd Justice to serve on this Court.
   “Justice White was born and raised in Colorado. He was a rare com-
bination of brilliant scholar and gifted athlete. He attended the Univer-
sity of Colorado, earning ten varsity letters, winning a Rhodes scholar-
ship to Oxford. Before attending Oxford, he played professional
football for the old Pittsburgh Pirates. When he returned from Oxford,
he attended Yale Law School while playing football for the Detroit
Lions on the weekends. He served as an intelligence officer for the
Navy during World War II.
   “Justice White was graduated from Yale Law School, earning the
Cullen Prize for high academic grades. He clerked for Chief Justice
Vinson and then returned home to Colorado where he practiced law
for fourteen years, before joining the Justice Department as deputy
attorney general under Robert Kennedy. Less than a year later, Presi-
dent Kennedy named him to the Court.
   “Justice White was an able colleague and a good friend. He came as
close as any to meriting Matthew Arnold’s description of Sophocles: he
‘saw life steadily and he saw it whole.’ All of us who served with him
feel a sense of personal loss. Our condolences go out to his wife, Marion,
his two children, and their families.
   “At an appropriate time in the fall, the traditional memorial observ-
ance of the Court and the Bar will be held in this Courtroom.”
                                Opinion
   No. 00–795. John D. Ashcroft, Attorney General, et al., Petitioners
v. The Free Speech Coalition, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Thomas concurring in
JNL01$0416—04-22-02 18:52:13       JOURNAPGT         MILES




778                        TUESDAY, APRIL 16, 2002

the judgment. Opinion by Justice O’Connor, with whom The Chief Jus-
tice and Justice Scalia join as to Part II, concurring in the judgment
in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice,
with whom Justice Scalia joins in part.

  No. 01–9324. Benjamin Tillman, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the

  No. 01–1053. Rondle Anderson, Superintendent, Indiana State
Prison, Petitioner v. Alan L. Matheney. Motion of respondent for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.
  No. 01–8496. Charles Fordjour, Petitioner v. California. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California dismissed.
See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s proc-
ess, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in non-
criminal matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by
Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1.
See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992)
(per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited
therein.
  No. 01–8601. Marvin D. Mayberry, Petitioner v. Mary Burghuis.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied,
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8.
  No. 01–8793. Terry L. Gibbs, Petitioner v. Jo Anne B. Barnhart,
Commissioner of Social Security. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit dismissed.
See Rule 39.8.
                        Habeas Corpus Denied
 No. 01–9279. In Re Fred Louis Lamp, Petitioner;
 No. 01–9280. In Re Bernard Jerry-El, Petitioner;

                       Attorney Discipline

  No. D–2298. In the Matter of Discipline of Jeffrey Steven Weiss.
Jeffrey Steven Weiss, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, is suspended from
the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–2299. In the Matter of Discipline of Jean Gilroy Gavlick. Jean
Gilroy Gavlick, of Wyomissing, Pennsylvania, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring her to show cause why she should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

  The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 29, 2002, until Mon-
day, May 13, 2002.

                        Attorney Discipline
  No. D–2300. In the Matter of Discipline of Stuart Joseph Bobrow.
Stuart Joseph Bobrow, of Glenview, Illinois, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–2301. In the Matter of Discipline of Robert Samuel Leo. Rob-
ert Samuel Leo, of Winchester, Massachusetts, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

Gilliland, of Dallas, Texas, is suspended from the practice of law in this

to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law
in this Court.

                               Opinions

   No. 00–1250. US Airways, Inc., Petitioner v. Robert Barnett. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer.
Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice O’Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Justice
Thomas joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter with whom Jus-
tice Ginsburg joins.
  No. 01–344. Tommy G. Thompson, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, et al., Petitioners v. Western States Medical Center, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Concurring
opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer, with
whom The Chief Justice, Justice Stevens, and Justice Ginsburg join.

  Jr.                                                    Lawton

  Adjourned until Monday, May 13, 2002, at 10 o’clock.


                                 Orders
   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Appellate
Rules 1, 4, 5, 21, 24, 25, 26, 26.1, 27, 28, 31, 32, 36, 41, 44, and 45 and
new Form 6.
   2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Appellate
Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 2002, and shall govern in
all proceedings in appellate cases thereafter commenced and, insofar
as just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
   3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit to
the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Appel-
late Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.
JNL01$0429—11-13-02 11:51:09     JOURNAPGT          MILES




836                       MONDAY, APRIL 29, 2002

  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Bankruptcy
Rules 1004, 2004, 2015, 4004, 9014, and 9027, and new Rule 1004.1.
  2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Bank-
ruptcy Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 2002, and shall gov-
ern in all proceedings in bankruptcy cases thereafter commenced and,
insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
  3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit to
the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Bank-
ruptcy Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2075 of
Title 28, United States Code.

  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure be, and they hereby
are, amended by including therein amendments to Civil Rules 54, 58,
and 81, and a new Rule 7.1, and Rule C of Supplemental Rules for Cer-
tain Admiralty and Maritime Claims.
  2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Civil Pro-
cedure shall take effect on December 1, 2002, and shall govern in all
proceedings in civil cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just
and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
  3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Civil Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.

   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Criminal
Rules 1 through 60.
   2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 2002, and shall govern in
all proceedings in criminal cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as
just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
   3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit to
the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Crim-
inal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.
JNL01$0429—11-13-02 11:51:09    JOURNAPGT         MILES




                         MONDAY, APRIL 29, 2002                 837
   Justice Scalia filed a statement respecting proposed Fed. Rule of

filed a dissenting statement.

   No. 01–9727. In Re John Dennis Snavely, Petitioner. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for
writ of habeas corpus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has re-
peatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
JNL01$0513—06-04-02 11:10:30     JOURNAPGT          MILES




880                        MONDAY, MAY 13, 2002

compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                                 Opinions

  No. 01–298. Paul Lapides, Petitioner v. Board of Regents of the Uni-
versity System of Georgia, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer.
  No. 00–1293. John Ashcroft, Attorney General, Petitioner v. Ameri-
can Civil Liberties Union, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the judgment of this
JNL01$0513—06-04-02 11:10:30    JOURNAPGT          MILES




884                       MONDAY, MAY 13, 2002

Court. The Chief Justice announced that Justice Thomas announced the
judgment of the Court and delivered the opinion of the Court with
respect to Parts I, II, and IV, an opinion with respect to Parts III–A,
III–C, and III–D, in which The Chief Justice, Justice O’Connor, and
Justice Scalia join. Opinion by Justice O’Connor concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Breyer concurring in
part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Kennedy, with
whom Justice Souter and Justice Ginsburg join, concurring in the judg-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
   No. 00–511. Verizon Communications Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission, et al.;
   No. 00–555. WorldCom, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Verizon Communi-
cations Inc., et al.;
   No. 00–587. Federal Communications Commission, et al., Petitioners
v. Iowa Utilities Board, et al.;
   No. 00–590. AT&T Corp., Petitioner v. Iowa Utilities Board, et al.;
and
   No. 00–602. General Communications, Inc., Petitioner v. Iowa Utili-
ties Board, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed in part and af-
firmed in part, and cases remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter in which Justice
Scalia and Justice Thomas join as to Part III, and in which Justice
Thomas joins as to Parts IV. Opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom
Justice Scalia joins as to Part VI, concurring in part and dissenting in
part. Justice O’Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of
these cases.
  No. 00–799. City of Los Angeles, Petitioner v. Alameda Books, Inc.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the judgment of this Court. The Chief
Justice announced that Justice O’Connor announced the judgment of
the Court and delivered an opinion in which The Chief Justice, Justice
Scalia, and Justice Thomas join. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concur-
ring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice
Stevens and Justice Ginsburg join, and with whom Justice Breyer joins
as to Part II, dissenting.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 00–1689. AT&T Communications of the Southwest, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Verizon Communications
Inc. v. Federal Communications Commission, 535 U. S. ––– (2002).
   No. 01–1079. Sheila K. Montgomery, Petitioner v. Maryland, et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Lap-
ides v. Board of Regents of University System of Georgia, 535 U. S.
––– (2002.

time denied.

of these motions.

                               Opinions
  No. 00–1214. Alabama, Petitioner v. LeReed Shelton. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. Judgment affirmed. Opin-
ion by Justice Ginsburg. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with
whom The Chief Justice, Justice Kennedy, and Justice Thomas join.
  No. 00–1531. Verizon Maryland Inc., Petitioner v. Public Service
Commission of Maryland, et al.; and
  No. 00–1711. United States, Petitioner v. Public Service Commission
of Maryland, et al. On writs of certiorari to United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and cases remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring
opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice Ginsburg and Justice
Breyer join. Justice O’Connor took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of these cases.
  No. 01–687. United States, Petitioner v. Leonard Cotton, Marquette
Hall, Lamont Thomas, Matilda Hall, Jovan Powell, Jesus Hall, and
Stanley Hall, Jr. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
JNL01$0520—10-22-02 21:24:49      JOURNAPGT          MILES




914                         MONDAY, MAY 20, 2002

to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by The Chief Justice.
  No. 00–878. Richard L. Mathias, et al., Petitioners v. WorldCom
Technologies, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Writ of certiorari
dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by
The Chief Justice. Justice O’Connor took no part in the decision of
this case.

tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 00–1699. BellSouth Telecommunications, Inc., Petitioner v.
North Carolina Utilities Commission, et al. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Verizon Maryland Inc. v. Public
Service Commission of Maryland, 535 U. S. ––– (2002). Justice O’Con-
nor took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

Brian Walter Chance, of Lowell, Massachusetts, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

                            Recess Order

  The Court will take a recess from today until Monday, June 3, 2002.

  No. 01–10406. In Re Napoleon Beazley, Petitioner. Application for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy
and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of habeas

petition.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 3, 2002                     947
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 00–1765. Pioneer Magnetics, Inc., Petitioner v. Micro Linear
Corporation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further consideration in
light of Festo Corporation v. Shoketsu Kinzoku Kogyo Kabushiki Co.,
535 U. S. ––– (2002).
   No. 00–1946. Insituform Technologies, Inc., Insituform (Nether-
lands) B. V., and Insituform Gulf South, Inc., Petitioners v. CAT Con-
tracting, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further
consideration in light of Festo Corporation v. Shoketsu Kinzoku Kogyo
Kabushiki Co., 535 U. S. ––– (2002).
   No. 01–35. Senior Technologies, Inc., Petitioner v. R. F. Technolo-
gies, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further consideration in
light of Festo Corporation v. Shoketsu Kinzoku Kogyo Kabushiki Co.,
535 U. S. ––– (2002).
   No. 01–269. Creo Products Inc., Petitioner v. Dainippon Screen Man-

the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further
consideration in light of Festo Corporation v. Shoketsu Kinzoku Kogyo
Kabushiki Co., 535 U. S. ––– (2002).

  No. 01–9451. Fa’Dee Mulazim, Petitioner v. Michigan Department of
Corrections, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As
petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is di-
rected not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from
petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and
petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District
of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice
Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit; Luis Gonzalez, et ux., Petition-
ers v. Lynne Riddle, et al.; and Luis Gonzalez, et ux., Petitioners v.
Eldorado Bank, et al. Application for stay addressed to Justice Gins-
burg and referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.

                               Opinions
  No. 01–408. The Holmes Group, Inc., Petitioner v. Vornado Air Cir-
culation Systems, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit
with instructions to transfer the case to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opinion by
Justice Stevens concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice O’Connor joins, con-
curring in the judgment.
  No. 01–147. Securities and Exchange Commission, Petitioner v.
Charles Zandford. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Stevens.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 10, 2002                       967
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and
Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                    Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 01–600. Gerald Mason, Warden, Petitioner v. Charlie Lee Mitch-
ell. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of Bell
v. Cone, 535 U. S. ––– (2002).

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 01A930. Isidoro Rodriguez, Petitioner v. Amlin Hazbun Escaf.
Application stay addressed to Justice O’Connor and referred to the
Court denied.
   No. 01M64. Rodolpho P. Munoz, Petitioner v. Tencil G. Munoz. Mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
   No. 01M65. Peter Petrovich, Petitioner v. Sands Casino & Hotel.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time under Rule 14.5 denied.
   No. 01M66. Joel Escobedo, Petitioner v. Texas. Motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency executed
by petitioner granted.
   No. 129, Original. State of Virginia, Plaintiff v. State of Maryland.
Motion of the Special Master for fees and reimbursement of expenses
granted, and the Special Master is awarded a total of $74,811.30 for the
period August 1, 2001, through April 30, 2002, to be paid equally by
the parties.
   No. 01–8880. In Re Douglas W. Thompson, Petitioner. Motion of
petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed
in forma pauperis denied.
JNL01$0610—06-20-02 18:16:35     JOURNAPGT          MILES

                   Appeals—Jurisdiction Noted
  No. 01–1437. Beatrice Branch, et al., Appellants v. John Robert

Branch, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Mississippi. In these cases probable jurisdiction
noted. Cases consolidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral
argument.

                       Attorney Discipline
   No. D–2315. In the Matter of Discipline of Thomas Eugene Reeks.
Thomas Eugene Reeks, of Tucson, Arizona, is suspended from the prac-
tice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2316. In the Matter of Discipline of Douglas M. Marshall.
Douglas M. Marshall, of Grand Forks, North Dakota, is suspended from
the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

Thomas B. Richey, of Fresno, California, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.

                               Opinions
   No. 01–455. Franconia Associates, et al., Petitioners v. United
States; and Grass Valley Terrace, et al., Petitioners v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Federal Circuit. Judgments reversed, and cases remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Ginsburg.
   No. 00–1614. National Railroad Passenger Corporation, Petitioner
v. Abner Morgan, Jr. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and re-
versed in part, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Opinion by Jus-
tice O’Connor with whom The Chief Justice joins, with whom Justice
Scalia and Justice Kennedy join as to all but Part I, and with whom
Justice Breyer joins as to Part I, concurring in part and dissenting
in part.
   No. 00–1406. Chevron U. S. A. Inc., Petitioner v. Mario Echazabal.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.
   No. 01–651. JPMorgan Chase Bank, Petitioner v. Traffic Stream
(BVI) Infrastructure Limited. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.
   No. 00–1187. David R. McKune, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. Robert
G. Lile. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
JNL01$0610—06-20-02 18:16:35     JOURNAPGT        MILES




                          MONDAY, JUNE 10, 2002                   987
the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the judgment of this Court. Justice Ken-
nedy announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in
which The Chief Justice, Justice Scalia, and Justice Thomas join. Opin-
ion by Justice O’Connor concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg,
and Justice Breyer join.
   No. 01–417. Robert J. Devlin, Petitioner v. Robert A. Scardelletti,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice O’Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice
Kennedy and Justice Thomas join.
