(JOURNAL)                  TUESDAY, JUNE 11, 2002                     989
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 01–10635. Willie Mack Modden, Petitioner v. Texas. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court granted pending disposition of the
petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ of certiorari
be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In the event the
petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall terminate upon
the issuance of the mandate of this Court. The Chief Justice, Justice
Scalia, and Justice Thomas would deny the application for stay of
execution.
JNL01$0617—11-13-02 10:09:35     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 17, 2002                     991
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Jus-
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”
                           Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 01–1385. Martin Horn, Commissioner, Pennsylvania Department
of Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. George E. Banks. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam.
                  Appeals—Summary Disposition
   No. 01–1126. J. B. Mayfield, et al, Appellants v. Texas, et al.;
   No. 01–1196. Simon Balderas, et al., Appellants v. Texas, et al.;
   No. 01–1225. Mexican American Legislative Caucus Texas House of
Representatives, Appellant v. Texas, et al.;
   No. 01–1242. Emily Amps, et al., Appellants v. Texas, et al.; and
   No. 01–1453. J. B. Mayfield, et al., Appellants v. Texas, et al. On
appeals from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Texas. Judgments affirmed.
                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 00–1231. Charles E. Simmons, Secretary, Kansas Department of
Corrections, Petitioner v. Marvin W. Johnston. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
for further consideration in light of McKune v. Lile, 536 U.S. ––– (2002).
  No. 00–1397. UAL Corporation, dba United Airlines, Petitioner v.
Joanne Fielder. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari

992                        MONDAY, JUNE 17, 2002

Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of National Railroad Passenger Corporation v. Morgan, 536 U. S. –––
(2002).
   No. 01–985. Sheri Sawyer Madison, Petitioner v. IBP, Inc. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of National Rail-
road Passenger Corporation v. Morgan, 536 U.S. ––– (2002).
   No. 01–1068. James Henderson, Petitioner v. General American Life
Insurance Company, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the

writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Devlin v. Scardelletti, 536 U. S. ––– (2002).
   No. 01–1205. Carolyn E. O’Connor, Petitioner v. Northshore Interna-

for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further
consideration in light of Swierkiewicz v. Sorema N. A., 534 U. S. –––
(2002).
   No. 01–1297. Charles L. Grimes and Gordon W. Chaplin, Trustees
Under the Will of Louise Chaplin, et al., Petitioners v. Navigant Con-
sulting, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Devlin v. Scardelletti, 536 U. S. ––– (2002).
   No. 01–1360. Randall C. Scarborough, Petitioner v. Anthony J. Prin-
cipi, Secretary of Veterans Affairs. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further
consideration in light of Edelman v. Lynchburg College, 535 U. S. –––
(2002).

   No. 01–9663. James Marcello and Olivia Marcello, Petitioners v.

See Rule 39.8.
   No. 01–9745. In Re Clyde Nubine, Petitioner. Motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Texas dismissed. See Rule 39.8.
As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is
directed not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters
from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid
and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v.
JNL01$0617—11-13-02 10:09:35    JOURNAPGT         MILES




                          MONDAY, JUNE 17, 2002                  1009
District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U.S. 1 (1992) (per curiam).
Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
  No. 01–10257. James M. DeBardeleben, Petitioner v. Michael V.
Pugh, Warden. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As
petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is di-
rected not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from
petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and
petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District
of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice
Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                                    Opinions

   No. 01–301. Tom L. Carey, Warden, Petitioner v. Tony Eugene Saf-
fold. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom The Chief Justice,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Thomas join.
  No. 01–463. United States, Petitioner v. Fior D’Italia, Inc. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice Scalia and Justice
Thomas join.
  No. 01–631. United States, Petitioner v. Christopher Drayton and
Clifton Brown, Jr. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
JNL01$0617—11-13-02 10:09:35     JOURNAPGT           MILES




                           MONDAY, JUNE 17, 2002                     1013
Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter with
whom Justice Stevens and Justice Ginsburg join.
   No. 01–682. Kay Barnes, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Jeffrey Gorman.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia.
Concurring opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice O’Connor
joins. Opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Ginsburg and Jus-
tice Breyer join, concurring in the judgment.
   No. 00–1737. Watchtower Bible and Tract Society of New York, Inc.,
et al., Petitioners v. Village of Stratton, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion
by Justice Breyer with whom Justice Souter and Justice Ginsburg join.
Opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Thomas joins, concurring
in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

  No. 01–10810. Wallace M. Fugate, III, Petitioner v. Frederick Head,

sented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court denied.

JNL01$0620—07-02-02 16:48:11     JOURNAPGT         MILES




(JOURNAL)                THURSDAY, JUNE 20, 2002                  1021
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                               Opinions

  No. 01–714. Utah, et al., Appellants v. Donald L. Evans, Secretary
of Commerce, et al. On appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Utah. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Breyer.
Opinion by Justice O’Connor concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Kennedy joins, concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Scalia.
  No. 01–419. City of Columbus, et al., Petitioners v. Ours Garage and
Wrecker Service, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Ginsburg. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with
whom Justice O’Connor joins.
  No. 00–1021. Rush Prudential HMO, Inc., Petitioner v. Debra C.
Moran, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Souter. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas with whom The Chief
Justice, Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy join.
   No. 01–394. Warren Christopher, Former Secretary of State, et al.,
Petitioners v. Jennifer K. Harbury. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the District of Columbia Circuit for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion
by Justice Thomas concurring in the judgment.
   No. 00–8452. Daryl Renard Atkins, Petitioner v. Virginia. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice with whom Justice
JNL01$0620—07-02-02 16:48:11     JOURNAPGT         MILES




1022                     THURSDAY, JUNE 20, 2002

Scalia and Justice Thomas join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia
with whom The Chief Justice and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 01–679. Gonzaga University and Roberta S. League, Petitioners
v. John Doe. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington.
Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Wash-
ington for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Breyer, with
whom Justice Souter joins, concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Ginsburg joins.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                        Opinion Per Curiam
   No. 01–8419. Kennedy D. Kirk, Petitioner v. Louisiana. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Cir-
cuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam.

  No. 01–1600. John Unger, II, et al., Appellants v. Joseph Manchin,
III, Secretary of State of West Virginia, et al. Appeal from the United

ment affirmed.

   No. 00–665. Jose Montemayor, Commissioner, Texas Department of
Insurance, et al., Petitioners v. Corporate Health Insurance, et al. On

vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Rush Prudential
HMO, Inc. v. Moran, 536 U. S. ––– (2002).
   No. 01–1028. City of San Antonio and Texas Towing Corporation,

Corrections, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As
petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is di-
rected not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from
petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and
petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District
of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice
Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                               Opinions
   No. 01–595. United States, Petitioner v. Angela Ruiz. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Opinion by
Justice Thomas concurring in the judgment.
   No. 01–488. Timothy Stuart Ring, Petitioner v. Arizona. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Arizona for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Ginsburg. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Justice
Thomas joins. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by Jus-
tice Breyer concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice
O’Connor with whom The Chief Justice joins.
   No. 00–10666. William Joseph Harris, Petitioner v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Justice Kennedy announced the
judgment of the Court and delivered the opinion of the Court with
respect to Parts I, II, and IV, and an opinion with respect to Part III,
with whom The Chief Justice, Justice O’Connor, and Justice Scalia join.
Concurring opinion by Justice O’Connor. Opinion by Justice Breyer
concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Thomas with whom Justice Stevens, Justice Souter, and Jus-
tice Ginsburg join.
JNL01$0624—07-15-02 20:09:02     JOURNAPGT         MILES




1044                      MONDAY, JUNE 24, 2002

   No. 01–518. BE&K Construction Company, Petitioner v. National
Labor Relations Board, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia with
whom Justice Thomas joins. Opinion by Justice Breyer with whom
Justice Stevens, Justice Souter, and Justice Ginsburg join, concurring
in part and concurring in the opinion.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “On Thursday, June 27, 2002, next Thursday, the Court will announce
all remaining opinions ready during this Term of the Court.”


  Adjourned until Thursday, June 27, 2002, at 10 o’clock.

                               Opinions
   No. 01–332. Board of Education of Independent School District No.
92 of Pottawatomie County, et al., Petitioners v. Lindsay Earls, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Thomas. Concurring opinion by Justice Breyer. Dissenting opinion by
Justice O’Connor with whom Justice Souter joins. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Ginsburg with whom Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor, and
Justice Souter join.
   No. 01–521. Republican Party of Minnesota, et al., Petitioners v.
Suzanne White, Chairperson, Minnesota Board of Judicial Standards,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice O’Connor. Concurring opin-
ion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with
whom Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Ginsburg with whom Justice Stevens, Jus-
tice Souter, and Justice Breyer join.
   No. 01–309. Larry Hope, Petitioner v. Mark Pelzer, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas with whom The Chief Justice
and Justice Scalia join.
   No. 00–1751. Susan Tave Zelman, Superintendent of Public Instruc-

Harris, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
The Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice O’Connor. Concurring
opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice Stevens, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Breyer with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Souter join.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “I am authorized to announce that the Court has acted on all cases
submitted for decision this Term. Disposition of items scheduled for
Conference will be reflected on the Order List that will be released at
10:00 a.m. tomorrow. Accordingly, it is ordered that those remaining on
the docket, but not ready for consideration, are continued to the session
of the Court the first Monday in October 7, 2002.
   “The Court will be in recess from today until the first Monday in
October 2002, at which time the October 2001 Term will be adjourned
and the October 2002 Term of the Court will begin as provided by law.
   “The Supreme Court building was closed for a short period begin-
ning on a Friday last October after hazardous substances were found
in the building. It is a tribute to the Court staff and the Bar that oral
arguments were not delayed. They were conducted in the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit courtroom
on three days the following week as scheduled.
   “The Court members thank all Supreme Court employees for their
outstanding work and their dedication to duty during this Term. The
Court, the Bar, and the public recognize hard work, commitment, and
professionalism of the Court staff. The work by the Court staff contrib-
utes significantly to the accomplishment of the Court’s mission.”


  Adjourned until Monday, October 7, 2002, at 10 o’clock.
JNL01$0628—07-15-02 20:10:42     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                  FRIDAY, JUNE 28, 2002                    1051
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                        Opinions Per Curiam
  No. 01–339. Terry L. Stewart, Director, Arizona Department of Cor-
rections, Petitioner v. Robert Douglas Smith. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
  No. 01–1471. United States, Petitioner v. John Bass. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam.

JNL01$0628—07-15-02 20:10:42     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                           FRIDAY, JUNE 28, 2002                   1055
Hyung Joon Kim. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States

   No. 01–1572. Cook County, Illinois, Petitioner v. United States,
ex rel. Janet Chandler. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted.
   No. 01–593. Dole Food Company, et al., Petitioners v. Gerardo Den-
nis Patrickson, et al.; and
   No. 01–594. Dead Sea Bromine Co., Ltd., and Bromine Compounds
Limited, Petitioners v. Gerardo Dennis Patrickson, et al. Petitions for
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit granted limited to the following questions: 1. Whether a corpo-
ration is an “agency or instrumentality” if a foreign state owns a major-
ity of the shares of a corporate enterprise that in turn owns a majority
of the shares of the corporation. 2. Whether a corporation is an “agency
or instrumentality” if a foreign state owned a majority of the shares
of the corporation at the time of the events giving rise to litigation,
but the foreign state does not own a majority of those shares at the
time that a plaintiff commences a suit against the corporation. Cases
are consolidated, and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument.
   No. 01–1500. Erick Cornell Clay, Petitioner v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit granted limited to the following question: Whether
petitioner’s judgment of conviction became “final” within the meaning
of 28 U. S. C. 2255 para. 6(1) one year after the court of appeals issued
its mandate on direct appeal or one year after his time for filing a
petition for writ of certiorari expired.

(JOURNAL)               WEDNESDAY, JULY 10, 2002                  1075
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                      Order in Pending Case
  No. 02A34. Michael W. Moore, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, Applicant v. Linroy Bottoson. Application to vacate the
stay of execution of sentence of death entered by the Supreme Court

Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                                  Order

   It is ordered that Christopher W. Vasil be appointed Chief Deputy
Clerk of this Court to succeed Francis J. Lorson effective at the com-
mencement of business September 3, 2002, and that he take the oath
of office as required by statute.
                               Order

  It is ordered that Cynthia J. Rapp be appointed Deputy Clerk of this
Court, effective at the commencement of business September 3, 2002,
and that she take the oath of office as required by statute.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 01–896. Ford Motor Company and Citibank (South Dakota),
N. A., Petitioners v. John B. McCauley, et al. Parties are directed to
file supplemental briefs addressing the following question: “Is there
appellate jurisdiction when petitioners, as the nominally prevailing
party in the district court, appeal the district court’s dismissal of a
complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction?” Briefs are to be filed
with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m.,
Thursday, September 26, 2002. Twenty copies of the briefs prepared
under Rule 33.2 may be filed initially in order to meet the September
26 filing date. Rule 29.2 does not apply. Forty copies of the briefs pre-
pared under Rule 33.1 are to be filed as soon as possible thereafter.
